unittitle.value: Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged and Indigent Females in New York City

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Eight volumes of records of the Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged and Indigent Females in New York City which was formally established in February of 1814. From its beginning until 1838 the women of the Association met regularly and visited the dependent pensioners with gifts of clothing, groceries and cash. In 1838 they expanded their scope by establishing an asylum for the pensioners at 20th Street near 3rd Avenue. The NYC telephone directories reveal that they continued operating at an Amsterdam Avenue address until 1968.

p.value: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)
This collection should be cited as BV Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged and Indigent Females of New York City, The New-York Historical Society.

Beginning with only 16 managers under the First Directress Ann Dominick in 1814, the Society grew quickly and on March 10, 1815 was incorporated. As "a body corporate and politic" the Society became known by its now recognized name Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged and Indigent Females. By 1838 the Board oversaw 4 other committees in addition to an Asylum built on 20th Street near 3rd Avenue to house and care for its "inmates," elderly female pensioners. The NYC telephone directories reveal that they continued operating at an Amsterdam Avenue address until 1968.

The 8 volumes in this collection depict the meetings, responsibilities, and actions of the Advisory Committee, or Board, of the Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged and Indigent Females in New York City. Though some gaps in years do appear between the volumes, there are included meeting minutes, expenditure books, and records of the pensioners for whom the Association cared. Also included are records of the Advisory Committee's visits to their Asylum during the years immediately following its construction in 1838. The volumes are arranged chronologically within each series.

subject.value: Older women -- New York (State) -- New York.

corpname.value: Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females

dsc.value:
Subseries I.1: Minutes of the Board of Trustees - Volumes Scope and Contents note

This subseries consists of Minutes of the Board of Trustees 1853-1951, bound in volumes, arranged chronologically. The first volume in the series briefly chronicles annual meetings 1854-1894. The following volumes contain the minutes of all meetings of the Board of Trustees, including annual meetings, monthly meetings, and special meetings 1853-1951. A volume of Minutes 1869-1879 from the Finance Committee, a subcommittee of the Board, is interfiled chronologically with the other board minutes. There is some duplication of information in volumes 3-5.

 Minutes of the Ladies Society for the Relief of RIAF 2 1814-1817 Receipts/Account Book of Extra Fuel for "Inmates" 6 1849-1862 Minutes of Advisory Committee Meetings 7 1867-1870 Minutes of Advisory Committee Meetings 8 1870-1883 Series II: Pensioners and Asylum Records Scope and Contents note

This series includes lists of pensioners visited by members of the association prior to the opening of the asylum, which contains the date of the entry, pensioners' names, pensioners' religious denomination, name of the member caring for them, remarks, and the date of pensioners' death if no longer living. Also in this series is a list of deaths at the asylum from its opening in 1838. Additionally included are notes made by members of the association recording the condition of the asylum during weekly visits.

 List of Pensioners 1 1813-1832 List of Deaths at the Asylum 3 1838-1875 Weekly Visiting Committee's Book 4 1839-1843 List of Out Door Pensioners 5 1844-1860
